A Channel that Heats Up

Tobias Koch ¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Amos Lapidoth ETH Zurich, Switzerland
Email: {tkoch, lapidoth}@isi.ee.ethz.ch ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Paul P.¬†Sotiriadis Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, USA
Email: pps@jhu.edu
Abstract

Motivated by on-chip communication, a channel model is proposed where the variance of the additive noise depends on the weighted sum of the past channel input powers. For this channel, an expression for the capacity per unit cost is derived, and it is shown that the expression holds also in the presence of feedback.

I Introduction

Continuous advancement in VLSI technologies has resulted in extremely small transistor sizes and highly complex microprocessors. However, on-chip interconnects responsible for on-chip communication have been improved only moderately. This leads to the ‚Äúparadox‚Äù that local information processing is done very efficiently, but communicating information between on-chip units is a major challenge.

This work focuses on an emergent issue expected to challenge circuit development in future technologies. Information communication and processing is associated with energy dissipation into heat which raises the temperature of the transmitter/receiver or processing devices; moreover, the intrinsic device noise level depends strongly and increasingly on the temperature. Therefore, the total physical structure can be modeled as a communication channel whose noise level is data dependent. We describe this mathematically in the following subsection.

I-A Channel Model

We consider the communication system depicted in Figure¬†1. I-B Capacity per Unit Cost

Let the rate RùëÖR (in nats per channel use) be defined as

R‚âúlog‚Å°|‚Ñ≥|n‚âúùëÖ‚Ñ≥ùëõR\triangleq\frac{\log|\mathcal{M}|}{n} (5)

where log‚Å°(‚ãÖ)‚ãÖ\log(\cdot) denotes the natural logarithm function. A rate is said to be achievable if there exists a sequence of mappings œïnsubscriptitalic-œïùëõ\phi_{n} (without feedback) or œÜn(1),‚Ä¶,œÜn(n)superscriptsubscriptùúëùëõ1‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùúëùëõùëõ\varphi_{n}^{(1)},\ldots,\varphi_{n}^{(n)} (with feedback) and œànsubscriptùúìùëõ\psi_{n} such that the error probability Pr‚Äã(M^‚â†M)Pr^ùëÄùëÄ\,\textnormal{Pr}\!\left(\hat{M}\neq M\right) tends to zero as nùëõn goes to infinity. The capacity Cùê∂C is the supremum of all achievable rates. We denote by C‚Äã(SNR)ùê∂SNRC(\textnormal{SNR}) the capacity under the input constraint (3) when there is no feedback, and we add the subscript ‚ÄúFB‚Äù to indicate that there is a feedback link. Clearly,

C‚Äã(SNR)‚â§CFB‚Äã(SNR)ùê∂SNRsubscriptùê∂FBSNRC(\textnormal{SNR})\leq C_{\textnormal{FB}}(\textnormal{SNR}) (6)

as we can always ignore the feedback link.

In this paper we study the capacities per unit cost which are defined as [1]

I-C The Main Result

Our main result is stated in the following theorem.

Theorem 1

Consider the above channel model. Then, irrespective of whether feedback is available or not, the corresponding capacity per unit cost is given by

CÀô‚Äã(0)=CÀôFB‚Äã(0)=12‚Äã(1+Œ±)Àôùê∂0subscriptÀôùê∂FB0121ùõº\dot{C}(0)=\dot{C}_{\textnormal{FB}}(0)=\frac{1}{2}\left(1+\alpha\right) (9)

where Œ±ùõº\alpha is defined in (2).

Theorem¬†1 is proved in Section¬†II. In Section¬†III we briefly discuss the above channel at high SNR. Specifically, we present a sufficient and a necessary condition on the coefficients {Œ±ŒΩ}subscriptùõºùúà\{\alpha_{\nu}\} for capacity to be bounded in the SNR.

II Proof of Theorem 1

In Section¬†II-A we derive an upper bound on the feedback capacity CFB‚Äã(SNR)subscriptùê∂FBSNRC_{\textnormal{FB}}(\textnormal{SNR}), and in Section¬†II-B we derive a lower bound on the capacity C‚Äã(SNR)ùê∂SNRC(\textnormal{SNR}) in the absence of feedback. These bounds are then used in Section¬†II-C to derive an upper bound on CÀôFB‚Äã(0)subscriptÀôùê∂FB0\dot{C}_{\textnormal{FB}}(0) and a lower bound on CÀô‚Äã(0)Àôùê∂0\dot{C}(0), and it is shown that both bounds are equal to 1/2‚ãÖ(1+Œ±)‚ãÖ121ùõº1/2\cdot(1+\alpha). Together with (8) this proves Theorem¬†1.

II-B Lower Bound

As aforementioned, the above channel (1) is not stationary, and one therefore needs to exercise some care in relating the capacity C‚Äã(SNR)ùê∂SNRC(\textnormal{SNR}) in the absence of feedback to the quantity

lim¬Øn‚Üí‚àû‚Å°1n‚ÄãsupI‚Äã(X1n;Y1n)subscriptlimit-infimum‚Üíùëõ1ùëõsupremumùêºsuperscriptsubscriptùëã1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëå1ùëõ\varliminf_{n\to\infty}\frac{1}{n}\sup I(X_{1}^{n};Y_{1}^{n}) (12)

(where the maximization is over all input distributions satisfying the power constraint (3)). In fact, it is prima facie not clear whether there is a coding theorem associated with (12). We shall sidestep this problem by studying the capacity of a different channel whose time-kùëòk channel output Y~k‚àà‚Ñùsubscript~ùëåùëò‚Ñù\tilde{Y}_{k}\in\mathbb{R} is, conditional on the sequence {Xk}={xk}subscriptùëãùëòsubscriptùë•ùëò\{X_{k}\}=\{x_{k}\}, given by

Y~k=xk+(œÉ2+‚àëŒΩ=‚àí‚àûk‚àí1Œ±k‚àíŒΩ‚ÄãxŒΩ2)‚ãÖUksubscript~ùëåùëòsubscriptùë•ùëò‚ãÖsuperscriptùúé2superscriptsubscriptùúàùëò1subscriptùõºùëòùúàsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùúà2subscriptùëàùëò\tilde{Y}_{k}=x_{k}+\sqrt{\left(\sigma^{2}+\sum_{\nu=-\infty}^{k-1}\alpha_{k-\nu}x_{\nu}^{2}\right)}\cdot U_{k} (13)

where {Uk}subscriptùëàùëò\{U_{k}\} and {Œ±ŒΩ}subscriptùõºùúà\{\alpha_{\nu}\} are defined in Section¬†I-A. This channel has the advantage that it is stationary & ergodic in the sense that when {Xk}subscriptùëãùëò\{X_{k}\} is a stationary & ergodic process then the pair {(Xk,Y~k)}subscriptùëãùëòsubscript~ùëåùëò\{(X_{k},\tilde{Y}_{k})\} is jointly stationary & ergodic. It follows that if the sequences {Xk}k‚â§0subscriptsubscriptùëãùëòùëò0\{X_{k}\}_{k\leq 0} and {Xk}k‚â•1subscriptsubscriptùëãùëòùëò1\{X_{k}\}_{k\geq 1} are independent of each other, and if the random variables XksubscriptùëãùëòX_{k}, k‚â§0ùëò0k\leq 0, are bounded, then any rate that can be achieved over this new channel is also achievable over the original channel. Indeed, the original channel (1) can be converted into (13) by adding

II-C Asymptotic Analysis

We start with analyzing the upper bound (11). We have

III High SNR Results

The channel described in Section¬†I-A was studied at high SNR in [4] where it was asked whether capacity is bounded or unbounded in the SNR. It was shown that the answer to this question depends highly on the decay rate of the coefficients {Œ±ŒΩ}subscriptùõºùúà\{\alpha_{\nu}\}. We summarize the main result of [4] in the next theorem. For a statement of this theorem in its full generality and for a proof thereof we refer to [4].

Theorem 2

Consider the channel model described in Section¬†I-A. Then,

i) lim¬ØŒΩ‚Üí‚àû‚Å°Œ±ŒΩ+1Œ±ŒΩ>0subscriptlimit-infimum‚Üíùúàsubscriptùõºùúà1subscriptùõºùúà0\displaystyle\varliminf_{\nu\to\infty}\frac{\alpha_{\nu+1}}{\alpha_{\nu}}>0\quad ‚üπ‚üπ\displaystyle\Longrightarrow sup_SNR¬ø 0 C_FB(SNR) ¬° ‚àû, (35)
ii) lim¬ØŒΩ‚Üí‚àû‚Å°Œ±ŒΩ+1Œ±ŒΩ=0subscriptlimit-supremum‚Üíùúàsubscriptùõºùúà1subscriptùõºùúà0\displaystyle\varlimsup_{\nu\to\infty}\frac{\alpha_{\nu+1}}{\alpha_{\nu}}=0 ‚üπ‚üπ\displaystyle\Longrightarrow sup_SNR¬ø0 C(SNR) = ‚àû, (36)

where we define, for any a>0ùëé0a>0, a/0‚âú‚àû‚âúùëé0a/0\triangleq\infty and 0/0‚âú0‚âú0000/0\triangleq 0.

For example, when {Œ±ŒΩ}subscriptùõºùúà\{\alpha_{\nu}\} is a geometric sequence, i.e., Œ±ŒΩ=œÅŒΩsubscriptùõºùúàsuperscriptùúåùúà\alpha_{\nu}=\rho^{\nu} for 0<œÅ<10ùúå10<\rho<1, then the capacity is bounded. Note that when neither the left-hand side (LHS) of (35) nor the LHS of (36) holds, i.e., when lim¬ØŒΩ‚Üí‚àû‚Å°Œ±ŒΩ+1/Œ±ŒΩ>0subscriptlimit-supremum‚Üíùúàsubscriptùõºùúà1subscriptùõºùúà0\varlimsup_{\nu\to\infty}\alpha_{\nu+1}/\alpha_{\nu}>0 and lim¬ØŒΩ‚Üí‚àû‚Å°Œ±ŒΩ+1/Œ±ŒΩ=0subscriptlimit-infimum‚Üíùúàsubscriptùõºùúà1subscriptùõºùúà0\varliminf_{\nu\to\infty}\alpha_{\nu+1}/\alpha_{\nu}=0, then the capacity can be bounded or unbounded.
